While well-intentioned, NEPA has evolved into a cumbersome and lengthy process that has increased costs and permitting timelines, preventing critical infrastructure from being built in the Fourth District of Arkansas and across the country. I introduced the SPEED Act, which will:

✔️Streamline the permitting process to return the law to its intended purpose.
✔️Shorten permitting timelines and reduce the frequency of frivolous litigation.
✔️Simplify the analysis required in NEPA documents, easing the burden on agencies.
✔️Clarify the definition of “Major Federal Act."
✔️Establish judicial review limitations for NEPA claims.

Cormorants continue to threaten the aquaculture industry, leading to significant economic losses for our state’s fish farmers. Arkansas ranks second in aquaculture-producing states which is why I was proud that @NatResources was able to bring a bill to committee markup today which addresses the major threat these predators present to one of our state’s most valuable resources.

Cattle farmers from the Natural State and across the country reserve the right to protect their livestock from predatory wildlife like the Black Vulture, which threatens their livelihood and ultimately leads to negative effects on livestock production. Our farmers face enough hardship from the natural elements to government overreach, and I’m pleased to see legislation come to @NatResources today to address this vital issue that impacts our state’s farming industry.

This afternoon, I had the pleasure of touring the Carbon Chicken Project in Fayetteville. This farm combines biochar and poultry litter to revitalize and enhance soil. This sustainable solution can be used anywhere from home gardens to large-scale farms. It was inspiring to see this farm in its early stages of development—Arkansas continues to be a leader in agricultural sustainability!
